reviews.review_text: I was a WoW player. I played every expansion, I did HC/Mythic raiding, I spent thousands of hours playing it. If I could go back and get this on launch day instead, I would do it in a heart beat.  If you are an MMO players, this is hands down the best MMO on the market. I've played every major MMO since Ultima Online back in the 90s. FFXIV has every element you could want in an MMO and executes them extremely well.  The class system, all classes being available on a single character, is amazing. No alts, not that you can't have them, you just don't need them.  The story is captivating, you actually want to read the quests and see what happens rather than just click through to get the objectives.  Speak of quests, there are a ton, even without the myriad of side quests, and only completeing the main story, you can reach level cap on a class. Then roll in dungeons, raids, leves, hunting logs, challenge log, etc etc etc there is never a shortage of things to do, and they have made all of them entertaining.  If you like MMOs even a little bit, stop reading and click the buy button.   Really, stop.  Why are you still reading.   Stop it! Go play FFXIV, seriously.
Not too great at first, but the game really opens up once you're about 2000 hours in.

Overview:   Incredibly polished and well endowed MMO. Almost every setting is tweakable and supports controllers as well, you get a game that offers you everything you payed for and witholds none of it.  It also uphold the name of Final Fantasy in good faith, probably a lot better than the newer FF games. The combat is a bit repetitive however, you've got a wealth of content to discover and quests that reward you well; dungeons from level 15 and up and lots of end-game content (but be prepared for hardcore type groups for the real end-game content, statics with schedules).   Pretty soon there's going to be an expansion and new classes so there's much more to look forward to as the game ages. The developer has done a great job at supporting the game thus far and I've seen no signs of them slowing down.  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+  Here's my breakdown between the positives and negatives of FFXIV:RR. +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+  -------(Positive things)-------  + Good writing!  + Lots of content!   + The Hildibrand questline is the best questline in any MMO hands down.   + You've got lots of customization for your character / your HUD / and homes if you're rich enough.  + Generally a nice community for an MMO except for the occasional try-hard who gets unreasonably upset.    ------(Negative things)-------  - This game is fetch quest hell, if you despise fetch quests more than anything then I do not recommend you play this game.  - The journey from level 1 to level 50 isnt that exciting. (this pretty much goes for all MMOs)  - RNG will occupy the vast majority of your end game time spent. Repeatedly run the same content over and over and over until you get that pretty blouse you wanted to glamour.  - If you want to stick to 1 class for running content, the gameplay will get stale fairly fast, which isnt unique to FF, many MMO titles suffer from this. There's no traits or choice options to customize your fighting or spells, just flat stat increases that don't change the gameplay in any way other than just becoming stronger. (And your strength primarily comes from your gears item-level) You will be at level 50 with typically around 3 abilitys you need to use repeatedly for combat, and then 3 special situation skills to use in.. special situations and 2 super abilities you save for oh-♥♥♥♥ moments.  This varies between the classes but I played as a White Mage, so basically my job was to repeatedly hit the 2 button to cast cure, and then sometimes use a spell called Esuna to remove conditions from myself or others, and then cast an AOE that made HP regen (which you need to keep refreshing for the party once it wears off). This was not very fun to me, so you have to rely on the game to throw variety in the dungeons or enemies to spice things up.   Usually it just boils down to memorizing boss mechanics and hoping nobody screws up. So essentially you're a bot following a strictly scripted fight and if you deviate from that you're most likely going to fail; This might be different for other people, but this is just how I felt after a while of doing end-game content.  -------  But, feel free to give it a go yourself! There's a free 14 day trial for FFXIV, so don't let my opinions get in the way of a potentially good time when you could test drive it for yourself. As far as MMOs come and whats avaliable at the moment, I still recommend you give FF a try since it's one of the best subscription based MMOs out there right now. But this one just isnt for me.   (I Still recommend it for MMO lovers!)
Over 500 games in my Steam games library. Only one of them gets played: This one.

See, I don't normally play MMO's. If I try one, it usually captures my attention for a solid week, then I lose interest, uninstall it, and never play it again.  This game? Oh man oh man. This game is great. I've only ever played free MMO trash around the web, but this one is by far THE BEST MMO I have ever played.  The combat is like you should expect; if you've played any other MMO, it plays similarly to what you would expect out of an MMO. There are a variety of classes that you can choose from as your battlecraft classes and, the best part, you can have every class on one character. This is especially helpful when you're doing end-game raid stuffs. Form one team, and depending on what your team has leveled, you can form different groups with the same team.  When I first started playing this game, as a low level I thought the gameplay was spectacular. Everything felt so fresh, and I felt like there was a bunch of things about the game I had yet to discover. Boy, was I right. Once I hit 50 (the max level for every class BEFORE Heavensward, which will increase that cap to 60), I felt like the game suddenly opened up to me. To this day, I still find that I have a LOT to do.  If you're looking for a great MMO to play and don't mind a monthly fee, look no further. Final Fantasy XIV will surely fill your MMO needs.

Started playing this game with some friends last week, they no longer get on as much. I'm playing this game for more than 7 hrs each day.  I'm addicted. Trying to get my friends to play with me. 'I'll play it when I want to.' Muh friends. Play alone now. Throw snowballs at strangers. Pretty fun game.  I've set aside money to buy the expansion already, if you're looking for an MMO to get into by yourself or with some buddies go with this one. You won't regret it. You also get 30 days free of play time so that's really nice.  Also one feature I REALLY enjoy is how you can play any class you want without having to create another character. You just have to hit lvl 10 in the class you started out in before you can start another one. You can even cross-over skills from one class to another!

Started playing in November 2015 Currently seeking way to plug in brain to FFXIV to accept it as my new matrix overlord  -Pros- Gets semiregular updates with bunches of new content Smooth, beautiful gameplay Easy to pick up and play Very immersive and cinematic Plenty of stuff to do besides grind dungeons Great community (judging by the server I'm on - Balmung) Job system is wonderful Glamouring gear is great especially at 'endgame'  -Cons- Somewhat limited inventory space if you're looking to handle several jobs at once Get 2 retainers (item storage NPC's) for free, also pretty limited inventory, every extra one (up to 8) costs $2 each per month. RNG will make you cry Queue times for dungeons/roulettes as DPS will make you cry Market Board is EXTREMELY volatile The conversations over shout that you walk into in Idyllshire and Ul'Dah will make you question the world's sanity There are no Lalafell Tossing Tournaments Don't ask about the peaches.

I'd have to say after getting two job classes to 60 and geared for the end game raid [Weeping City of Mhach] this MMO defenitly has something for everyone. There's two pages of dungeons, 8 and 24 man raids, trial bosses, visually appealing, very helpful community, and most important it is not Pay to Win cash shop items are cosmetic. It has a captivatiing story, that follows the general cross game lore very well, as well as a very unique skill system allowing classes to use skills from other classes you may have.

So I just tested this game for a bit and I have to say it is a very good game.   Though I tested a lot of mmo's this is the only one beside World of Warcraft which kept me playing for longer than a month.   It has some similarities to other mmo's but also some differences, which in my opinion make this a better mmo than other ones.  Pro: - you only need 1 character - nice graphics - awesome community - tactical gameplay for raids (some are very tricky) - multiplatform - much pretty stuffs :3 - Lalafell  Con: - much instancing of areas due to console support   So i don't really have much negative to say. For people who come to this mmo from other mmo's might be a bit upset about a 'slacky and slow' combat due to a long global cooldown. But for me after a while playing this it is not a problem. Due to many mechanics some bosses have it is very good to have a longer gcd to react to the mechanics and it also makes the fights much more tactical than in other mmo's. I think it is for everyone to decide if u like this kind of combat and gameplay. But for pretty reasons this game is awesome and also Lalafell.  For people who don't want to instantly buy this, there is a free trial version you can test out. Just give it a try and decide for yourselves. Though it get's even better when you buy the full version and get to max level.  I hope this may help some people to decide.  I wish everyone a good night and enjoy your games.

One of the best MMORPGS since The days of vanilla WoW and Everquest II. One of the things that sets this game apart from current mmo's is the idea that your character is a person just like you. What I mean by that is that your character is not defined as a Mage or warrior, but rather someone who has learned how to be a Mage or warrior; in FFXIV, you can have one character that masters all classes and all professions. Professions (crafting classes) are very unique in that each crafting profession gets skills to help them in the world, for example, the fisherman profession around level 10 gets a sneak skill so they can traverse the world without being attacked. The fighting classes are separated into decouples of war, and decouples of magic; each with gear specified uniquely for it. The fighting classes include gladiator, pugalist, marauder, lancer, archer and rogue. The magic classes include the thaumaturge, the conjurer, and the arcanist.  What is so incredibly awesome about FFXIV is how all of these classes can be combined with another to create a more powerful and unique class. For example, you can create a paladin by getting your character to level 30 with a gladiator, and getting to level 15 with the conjurer, to create a slight mix of the two.  This game will forever be in my heart as the most immersive MMORPG and the mmo that has truly been worth a monthly payment. If I talked about everything in FFXIV, I'd be here all day typing, but in short, if you are questioning the value of this game, give the trial a try and you will quickly find out if you are a fan. Specs wise, the game runs beautifully, and for a game made quite a while ago, it graphically has withstood the test of time. I would recommend this game to any gamer who is searching for a great community, a great immersive experience, and a great breathe of fresh mmo air.

Do you like Final Fantasy 14? Their early work was a little too unfinished for my tastes, but when Final Fantasy XIV A Realm Reborn came out in 2013, I think they really came into their own, commercially and artistically. The whole game has a clear, crisp gameplay, and a new sheen of consummate professionalism that really gives the game a big boost. It's been compared to Guild Wars 2, but I think FF14 has a far more bitter, cynical sense of humor. In 2015, SquareEnix released this, Heavensward, their most recent expansion. I think their undisputed masterpiece is the fight against Ultima Weapon, a boss fight so enjoyable, most people probably don't dodge all of his abilities. But they should, because it's not just about the pleasures of conformity, and the importance of trends, it's also a personal statement about the developers themself. Hey Paul!

After experiencing all there is to offer, I can't honestly recommend this to someone looking for a faithful paid MMO in its current state. Sure, it's pretty fun for a while, but it gets too demanding and monotonous to enjoy playing in the long run, unless that's what you're into. Heavensward, the $40 expansion, is a well played joke. Multiplying the exp requirement for leveling and making you hike across massive maps* makes up more of this expansion's playtime than actual content. Significant updates are few and far between.  *Flying isn't unlocked for the area until you've activated every Aether Current across the map and awarded via quests, and by that time you're moving on to the next area anyway, where the process repeats.  TL;DR : A fantastic aesthetic, amazing soundtrack, accessible combat system and engaging story masks a life draining waiting simulator plagued with bad dev choices and Chinese RMT bots.  I'd like to hear from those who still stand by this game, as I can't fathom why.

This review is subjected to changes since it's an MMO which goes on a continous implementation of patches. As a veteran player I do not recommend this game. It's super bland grindy at the end game.  TL;DR - End Game content (Very important in all MMO): Live letter which boasts and sugar coats about upcoming patch/expansion > patch/expansion gets released > Content worth only 1 week or more of actual fun > Game gets bland and just daily grind heavy even with the new patch > becomes pretty dead for over 2 1/2 month until next patch > cycle repeats..  If your new or want to try a new mmo then try this game out. Graphics, story, leveling process and user interface is what will keep you captivated. It becomes only but a grind game at the end game content. Every cycle the director would say a very big update that is coming will improve the game.  At the end...it ends up being the same grinding content with the same agenda to kill a monster or do a dungeon (where you kill a monster too), or other similar elements that is sugar coated in different animation/graphics. Example in game - Diadem.  Many Veteran players have left this game and many have unsubscribed who resubscribes when a patch gets released which brings their hope up that the game got better but then unsubscribes disappointed. The majority of the players now that are recommending this game are players who have recently just started the game months ago and don't understand the cycle and brags how good this game is with having no experience on the entire game. Also some loyal fans.  Pros and Cons of this game:  Raid - If you are a hardcore player, you'll be disappointed from the fact that these raids lasts about a week and a half until hardcore players complete it. After completion, the next set of raids do not get released for another 2 1/2 month or even more. In other words their short. This applies to the 24 man raid as well. In heavensward expansion there has been twice where no raid content was released for 6 month each. Making it 12 month total now. They usually release 4 8-man raids every patch and 1 24-man raid every 2 patches. WoW on the otherhand has raids that lasts for months or a year because they release it in Huge contents and content itself is much harder then this game.  Dungeons - This is joke. Lasts about a day or two and then it becomes a simple repitiion and grind. The problem with dungeons is that every new dungeon they release, which is about 2 dungeons each patch, makes the old dungeons obsolete which they seem to take out of blizzard text book. However, a good element of the dungeon is that they do bring a new style of fights usually which is displayed on the boss fights. It's another grind just letting you know.  Crafting & Gathering - In no way, this element within any MMO is the Bread and Butter. It's useless and a game can be entirely enjoyable without it. This is just another form of grinding to make money within the game or make gears so players stay subscribed longer. The unique part though this game has a different style of system for crafting and gathering which makes it like you are actually fighting a monster with crafting skills. It requires some brain and once you get it down you can just make a macro, and sleep over night and let it do everything. That's all there is but let me say this element isn't the one to draw people to the game and people who say it is...haven't played other MMOs before and haven't tried all other content to it's fullest in any MMO.  Character/Leveling - One of the Best in the game because one character can do everything like one character can become Mage, Lancer, Paladin, Warrior, etc. You can switch any time, and level each one individually. Every time you level a different class, you get a 50% more experience if you have another class that is higher then the current class your leveling.  User Interface- ANOTHER BEST THING iN THIS GAME by far. You can literally customize it the way you want and save it in 4 different slots. Load up one slot if you changed to a healer example.   Controller support - had controller support back in FFXI and it works out pretty well in here too.  Netcode - it sucks. Play as a caster to get a visual experience of it when casting and moving. You can get a friend to see movement between both screen also to get the idea.  Player Versus Player Classes - Classes in this game are very imbalanced. Warrior and Summoner being the strongest.  Player Versus Player Arena - Called Feast(Score Match) and Wolves den(Death Match). First due note that the netcode sucks in this game so get ready to experience some server lag. Also, they haven't resolved to deal with the cheaters that boost points during a season. Every season lasts about 1 patch and some people at the top 100 are involved in cheating to boosting their points higher. The FFXIV team did nothing to deal with them. Instead left them alone which you can see in the forum. The Score match Arena modes are based on Guild Wars 2 style. Needs lots more polishing. There is no pure PVP death match because they made it obsolete with the release of Feast and advertising it. Also, every arena requires one healer, one tank, one range and one melee. So you can imagine how que time can be...It's worse in frontlines.   Player Versus player Frontlines - Or Open field fights. They absolutley do not know what they're doing with this. It's legit terrible and they haven't fixed anything in this regards:  1) 3 way team and if your in a Team that has a large population in the data center then expect a hour long que to just get in to a frontline match. 2) All of the frontline is usually the same with heavy RNG involved except secure mode which was the first frontline to exist.  3) Every patch that contains a new frontline, they make the old one obsolete just like blizzard does. You'll never experience the old Frontline content because they don't care about the players. 4) Finally Fourth - They do not listen to community feedback regarding to removing 3 way team both on Japanese and Global forums. Examine the forums, they have widely petition to remove it to improve que time but the FFXIV Team just ignores it. QUE TIME AND GRINDING ARE THE WORST thing in this game.  Feedback system - cater to japanese/new player mainly and barely listen to any feedbacks except for those people. That's why we have grind content still.. Director doesn't know what he's doing since heavensward and doesn't learn.  Cash Shop - It's becoming ridicolous now. They have a mount for 30 USD bucks. Cosmetics and other stuff as well. They are using it for milking cash from the loyal people.  Events - These Events are lined up during the 2 1/2 month drought period to keep people subscribed. Like literally, it's the same grindfest. For example look at the current Yo-Kai Watch event. Heavy grind for 2 month.  Marks - All your doing is farming for these at the end to get the latest gear. Before you know it next patch comes and the gear you have becomes useless...seriously happens to everyone.  Bags and storage - Item storage is really the worst in this game to a point that you won't have no space and IN CASH SHOP YOU HAVE TO BUY A RETAINER WHICH YOU PAY '3 Dollar per month' to have more space..yeah more subscription money.  Community - Excellent for new players. When it comes to discussing the dark side of the game, you'll see those topic silent. Listen to LimitBreakRadio and their community cuz they keep it real about the game.  Fanfest event will either break or make it for me. However, be very cautious about the stuff they say and show because it's just another grind content. There are huge content droughts since pre-expansion and Director is only making content for new players.  *Update seems like the players who started playing recently during Heavensward are downvoting this. They have no experience of endgame content Grinding Fantasy XIV Ladies and Gentleman!

TL;DR Play it if you like MMOs or come from WoW. Very fun game, and is the second most popular ATM but it should be most.  This is the most fun I've ever had in an MMO. It is pretty similar to WoW, but some slight changes like the GCD is 2.5 seconds by default instead of 1.5 or so in WoW.  There is so much to do in this game, the End game is MUCH more fun than WoW and much more rewarding. It is a themepark MMO so don't expect to not have to do Story to unlock much of the stuff in the game. It is the best way to level your first class and unlock new things. It's also very interesting so DON'T SKIP IT!   Another thing that makes it much better, is you only need one character (I believe there is a very good reason to have 2 characters if you get heavily into crafting, but I haven't so idk), but you can play every single class in the game on that character. This makes the game much more fun to play and not having to do the same quests over and over again to level your class.   I would recommend this game to Anyone who comes from WoW, or is just interested in a new MMO in general. So much fun.

Realm Reborn is a sequel to the previously released Final Fantasy XIV, which wasn’t received very well, and this is even conveniently explained in the game’s plot: there’s an apocalypse which ravages the whole realm and begins a new era. Personally I hadn’t played the previous game but this sequel is said to offer significant improvements over the original across the board, it's essentially an entirely redesigned game of its own.  The plot is fairly generic save the world kind of stuff: you are an adventurer brought into one of the game’s three big city-states with a special ability to attune to crystals which hold some great ability to hold off evil. You perform tasks for the city-states and eventually rise to become an envoy between them and even serve them. Similar to single-player games, the main plot and many of the other quests are filled with cutscenes, and in the main story’s case, the significant ones are also voiced. It’s all easy to follow and they’ve tried to put a bit of story into everything, for instance all of the game’s class guilds have a storyline of their own that advances as you gain levels and do guild quests.  However this kind of plot is well suited for MMO and something as complex as Final Fantasy XIII’s super messy plot obviously wouldn’t work here. Rising in guild ranks and joining armies feels like an accomplishment, and you get treated to far more heroic stuff like taking on massive primals (think summons from previous Final Fantasy titles) rather fast. The game overall plays much like a singleplayer game story wise: the story is focused on your personal character and many plot advancing quests have certain “duty” sections that can only be completed with your own character, such as taking on a boss battle. This can be reversed too in some cases: some boss battles and dungeons instead put you in a party with others. Most of the game can be soloed if you want, but the option to do stuff in a party is totally there too, you’ll only ever be separated for brief periods at a time.  This focus on your own character is what sets the game apart from other MMOs in my opinion and makes the game more interesting. The cutscenes are also no worse quality than in singleplayer FF titles and the game’s graphics and particularly animation are fantastic. All characters are lively animated and seeing your character pull off all kinds of stuff like stupid faces in cutscenes is really fun and involving. The game is also really well optimized, running on a large variety of systems and even having its own preset settings for laptops for instance that take your specs into account. The user interface in the game is really good too, super easy to use and slick looking, I was never at a loss to find something.  Gameplay is similar to other MMO titles and the difficulty level is really good across the board, you will be challenged at every level and you can always find more dangerous or easier opponents and quests. As a nice twist your character can be literally any class in the game – you can use and level any one class at a time, provided you have joined their guild, and certain class abilities can also be used by other classes. For instance, Gladiators that have leveled Conjurer can cast Cure, which they normally wouldn’t have access to, so cross-classing a bit is encouraged and even required to get Jobs (specialized mid/late-game classes) later on. To swap a class you just swap to a different gear preset, which you can create lists of. At the most basic level you just need to change a weapon to switch to another class.  The game is easy to get into as well, there’s a 15 day free trial that offers leveling of a single character up to level 20, but you can cross-class him/her as much as you like, and it’s definitely enough to get a good look at the game. The free trial is best played with a friend that already owns the game though, because you cannot set up your own parties in it, but other subscribed players can invite you to theirs. Marketplace and trading functions are limited but otherwise there’s no significant restrictions. The game is available as a digital download on the website and on Steam, as well as on PS3 and PS4 on the consoles, the multiplayer is cross-platform, and new buyers of the game automatically get 30 free game days. Steam users will also be happy to know that the monthly subscription can be paid with just Steam wallet money, assuming you also bought the game from Steam.  TL;DR  It's great. Don't compare it to Square Enix's other new FF games. It's a traditional MMO game with Final Fantasy flavor and one well designed one at that. I enjoy it tons more than the recent main series FF games. And I wrote this review originally for something else in mind, if you're wondering why it's so long and detailed. :P Give it a chance, it deserves more PC Steam players. And, it has a ton of content in a large world. I still feel like I've barely scratched the surface of what it has to offer so far at the moment of writing.
It's a fun game but a ton of work. When you get to mid/end game you'll probably have a lot on your plate. Just make sure you have a lot of time to play this game.

*tagged as a Drunk Review*  MMOs are incredibly hard to review.  They require a very different consumption model than the one which follows any other game constuct.  As having almost 4000 hours played would imply, I have a deep invesment into the game if, anything, to prove that I have not wasted over three months of my life playing it.  But it is far more enjoyable than any MMO I have played in the last 10 years.  Being able to play one character who can level anything? Godsdamned priceless.  A crafting system that (before Heaven's Ward) rewarded multiclassing? Superb.  Gathering that is wholly necessary to advance crafting returns? Essential to a proper balance of skills and classes.  A variety of class roles and requirements, wholly integral to endgame content? Fascinating and complicated.  This is the MMO that brought me back after nearly 7 years of exile from WoW.  Enjoy it, love it, find solace in the various game design decisions that benefit the solo player and bring so many options to the multi-player.  But don't get too invested in PvP. It is an afterthought that, while moderately balanced, is not nearly as fun and intuitive as the rest of the game is,  Lula Moon, Faerie server, Lv51+ in every job/class available.

This is easily the best MMO I've played in years. The graphics are beautiful, the character creation is very in-depth, and it actually feels like you're involved in the combat instead of just sitting there tapping buttons until you fall asleep. The crafting system is unique and fun (albeit frustrating sometimes), too. If you get bored of questing, dungeoning, and crafting, you can go play games and race chocobos at the Golden Saucer, if you're so inclined. You'll never run out of things to do in this game.  And if you're a roleplayer like me, Balmung has a huge and varied roleplay community--you're more than likely to find what you're looking for, no matter what your RP style is.  The only thing I don't like about the game is the character creation restrictions. If a server is overpopulated, you can't make a new character on it, and have to wait until the populated is a bit lower, which is usually really early in the morning (if you're in America). This is a huge problem on Balmumg, which really stinks if you're looking for an RP server. Other than that, though, this game is great and totally worth the $15 a month.

Best P2P MMO I've played in recent years. Been a few months since I have played so this might not be completely accurate. Here are my positives (+) negatives (-) and neutrals (o).  (+) All classes on one character, each levels individually, Mix and match (some) skills from one class to another. For example, if you plan to play a healer, 'Swift Cast' from the offensive caster is absolutely required so you can revive people instantly.  (+) This is the ultimate callback game for fans of the more classic Final Fantasy games, though you'll find a little bit from every game here. You probably don't need to be an FF fan to enjoy this, it stands up on its own mechanically. I would basically describe this game as 'WoW done better.'  (+) Level scaling for Dungeons and FATES (Fates are over-world events that people can take part in as a community.) So no matter what level you are, you and your friends can play together. However, you cannot level scale on the overworld unless you're inside a FATE.  (+) Party Finder. It works wonders, just queue up and do most anything else while you wait for a party to be automatically formed for a dungeon. You can also join overworld parties. Tanks and Healers will be matched quicker because they are not as commonly played, expect to wait if you are a DPS.  (+) Glamour system, make any piece of equipment look like another. You can only unlock the ability to glamour at level 50, but people can do it for you before then. It IS possible to look like a classically colored Black Mage, if you have the currency for it.  (+) Mechanically difficult and exhilarating bosses. Knowing how each dungeon and boss fight works before going in is essential to success. This is a double-edged sword, however, you could be stuck on a difficult fight, wiping multiple times with a pub party that doesn't know what they are doing. Sometimes it can get a bit too stressful, you'll always be on the razor's edge, late game. Different classes and roles are easier or harder to play, I wouldn't recommend rolling a tank for your first class.   (+) Guilds, Guild Houses and Homes. I highly recommend finding a good guild, there are benefits to reap. Decorate your own Guild House, Personal House or Apartment Room inside your Guild House. You could make your own guild, but I recommend joining an existing one that has some legs and good community.  (+) Chocobo Companions. Train a Chocobo to fight alongside you on the overworld, good for soloing. They can be mix-ups of Tank, Healer and DPS. Though the tank isn't all that good, last I heard.  (+) Gold Saucer and Minigames! Gamble, collect cards and play tetra master across the world (love it or hate it), race Chocobos FF7 style, earn currency for rewards.  (+) Retainers, get one of these as soon as you can, you get up to two for free. They act as your bank and you can send them out on missions to get items for you.  (o) Crafting is still kind of a pain like most MMO's, you do not draw from resources directly from your bank like in GW2, so it's an inventory management headache, but there is money to be made and it's far from useless. Each crafting class works mostly the same, but each has some unique skills that can cross-class like combat classes do. Many of which are necessary. It's worth a try.  (o) Arena and Mass-Scale PvP is available, though I can't comment on it since it's not my playstyle. EDIT: Recent update added 1v1 dueling.  (-) Ability Icon Clutter, a carry-over from WoW. This can be mitigated with good macro building and UI customization management, though.  (-) Main storyline isn't interesting until around level 50, which is max level before the expansion. Before that, there are some highlights, but it's mostly a slog through lots of political dialogue. Post vanilla is a vast improvement, though. Also, side story arcs are a lot better, for example, each class has its own story arc.  (-) No cross-server play. If you have a max level character on one server, and your friend is on another, one of you will have to make a new character or pay money for a server transfer.

The graphics on this game are amazing. It also scales well across old and new technology.  I am a die-hard WoW fan, and will probably always play it on-and-off until it ends, but this game might be the first major MMO to catch my attention. It all just works. The first few levels are a bit disorientating, but after level 5 it starts to make sense. The community is also young (as the game is new) but very polite and helpful.  There's a decent variety of classes to start off with, and those who hate alts will love that they can switch classes just by changing weapons after a certain point in the game. (Level 15?) WIth some hybrid classes only being available after you level two individual classes to 30/15 respectively. There's almost a guarentee of many many more classes coming over from the previous FFXI title. Ideally it would flesh out every primary class with two specialization choices-- like how Arcanist must choose between Summoner or Scholar. Classes famous from XI include: Samurai, Black Knight, Corsair, Theif, Red Mage, and Blue Mage.  So far quests are varied and interesting, the enviroments are vibrant, and the world feels alive. I have not experienced any lag client or server side.   If you like classic Final Fantasy, you'll love this game. It's a very solid title and worth a shot.

Square Enix goes above and beyond to make this a great title among MMOs. Every aspect of the game is really nice to look at, beautiful scenery to appreciate while running around and a lot of flair to every action made by the characters. The story is deep and engaging with a good level of charm to keep things amusing, as is standard with the final fantasy series as a whole. There is a whole lot more strategy to crafting as well, with a system that makes it much more interactive than clicking a button and waiting for 20 things to be done at once (which you can still choose to do to streamline the process if you're not concerned with a loss in experience or a higher failure rate). With the ability to swap between all the classes in the game at any time on the same character, you'll never even need to create more than one to experience everything, there are even specialised story quests for each class for you to enjoy. Whether you're leveling all your classes to the cap level, crafting up a storm and making money, destroying false gods to deck out your gear or just making your house look nice, you'll never run out of things to do either. All in all, probably the best MMO I've had the pleasure of experiencing, I highly look forward to the next update and I can't see myself stopping any time soon. Give it a go, it's definately worth the price even if you only play it for the first month.  If you didn't want to read all that then here's the short version: This game is better than any other MMO I've played, you should buy it.

This game is an overall amazing and stunning MMO to play and my favorite yet. It is very rare to find an MMO that just completely nails so many amazing features at once. This game has a very nice social aspect to it with a wide variety of emotes, housing, mini games, guilds and more that just allow the very large player base to interact like few other MMOs. I can't believe I haven't reviewed this yet, but my play time should speak for itself. Do not confuse this game with the atrocity that was XIV 1.0. Square Enix literally dropped a Bahamut meteor on that game to crash the servers and reimagine it as the beautiful experience it is today. Graphics are top-notch, at least if you have a decent enough rig to play it on high quality. The community overall is incredible, though your experience will vary by server, play times, and free company allegiance (FFXIV's version of guilds). Inter-played cooperation is mandatory for endgame content, and the game sets you up very nicely to learn your chosen role well by level 50. And then if you decide you don't like that role... all you have to do is switch weapons to a different class and try again.  Hallelujah, no more multiple characters to play multiple classes; I'm looking at you, WoW. Final Fantasy's job system makes it totally feasible to level every class to cap without having to jam up a server with 10 different characters, and you might be surprised by the number of people that do exactly that. Even the crafting system is much more interactive than others I've tried, and it's the crafters and gatherers that drive the game's economy. The sense of community is all-inclusive with plenty of experienced players willing to lend a hand to upstarts, though of course don't expect everyone to be this way. Like any game, this one has its elitists but the funny part is that some of those still haven't beaten the last raid.  The best pieces of advice I can give you are these:  1) If you buy the game, give it until around level 30 to start getting truly fun. That's where you unlock your job (as opposed to your class), earning you extra abilities, and it's where the dungeons start to get really fun. 2) Once you hit level 50, there is a HUGE learning curve jump when you get to extreme mode primals and the Coils of Bahamut. That's not to say these things are impassable, but you will have to buckle down and learn the mechanics rather than expecting a clear on your first try. 3) If you get lost, use the /sh shout function in chat. Talk to someone! I can almost guarantee there will be someone around to lend a helping hand. 4) Listen when people give you advice. 90% of the time, they say it because they want to help improve their server's experience, not because they think you're a n00b that sux. 5) If you're new to the game and chose the Brynhildr server, hit up Taliel Sicilian. ;)

NEW VERSION I got in after about a day of trying to get into the server. Once you're settled in, it takes at most 30 seconds to queue into the server on prime time.  I play a tank and I get a lot of love because of that. It appears tanks are extremely rare in this game. I always get the award for playing the most needed class. This is an actual reward in the game.  TUTORIAL The tutorial is huge and extremely good. It's not the type of tutorial that holds your hand, treats you like a baby and gives you little bites. It's a big tutorial that lasts throughout the entire first half of the leveling process. More features of the game open up over time, similar to Guild Wars 2's new player experience but not silly like in GW2.   There are obvious tutorial instances that teach the basics of the trinity and let you actually train and figure out how the mechanics work before you get thrown into a dungeon.  DUNGEONS + DUNGEON ROULETTE There's lots of them. Main quest dungeons, sidequest dungeons, instances that only have a boss in them, etc.  How does it prevent dungeons from being empty? The duty roulette system gives you a massive boost in rewards once per day. You don't pick a specific dungeon. The roulette picks it for you, meaning you never know what you'll get. Meanwhile, players who need to do a dungeon for their quests/items/gear will get their parties filled.  I'll compare this with GW2 that has a party finding/LFG tool. In there, you need to actually search for party members, which works ok witht he LFG tool. In Guild Wars 1 there was no such tool and you could end up waiting for hours to get a party.  WAITING FOR PARTY As I said before, the roulette fills up parties for massive rewards. It's not unheard of to get nearly an entire level worth of exp using the daily roulette. But how fast does it fill up? For me, as soon as I click the button to start up the search.  Why? Because I'm a tank and the guy who dragged me into this game is a healer. We only need to find 2 more DPS guys, of which there are bazillions.   As a tank, I get friend requests all over. People are overly friendly to me. In chats and forums there is talk of not enough tanks in this game. Since I am one, I don't have a problem. But if you prefer playing DPS, you may end up waiting for a while. I've seen players complain about waiting 30 minutes or more.   COMBAT Okay, I'm not a fan of the combat. All I do is press 2 buttons, maybe 3 and just rotate through them. Dungeons may have a few more rotations. Just fighting in the overworld is pretty lame.  Dungeon encounters are quite interesting though. You have the regular trash mobs leading up to the boss. Early bosses are pushovers. They gradually get better  CRAFTING There's a huge expansive crafting system. In fact, the gathering classes and crafting classes are quite fleshed out, similar to the combat classes.  In the beginning it is the old basic ingredient gathering and putting them together. Later on, you need to start making choices, mixed in with a bit of RNG. Using CP, Crafting Points, which are similar to mana points, you can activate skills that can improve the quality of an item, do nothing for a step (this has a use), make you more focused, etc.   Again, comparing with GW2... In GW2 you put 2-4 items together and press craft. That's it. Here, you put 2-5 (or 6?) items together, but they can be of different qualities, which affects the outcome. You activate skills which further change the outcome. Crafting one item takes several steps. These are not ingredient steps but 'attacks' you do. It's not braindead coma crafting.  USEFULNESS OF CRAFTING IN EARLY LEVELS Crafting is actually useful here, even in early levels. I did outlevel my crafting level. I mean, my main tank character got to level 38 but my blacksmith and armorsmith are still around 10. I didn't even need to craft items for my char to use because I got all ym gear from main-quest quest rewards. But that's just one class. There are many other classes and your character can take them all. You onlyneed one character. To swap jobs you swap out your gearset.  When I start building my disciples of magic classes, I'll want to craft a bit for those.  Also, all the quest rewards are normal quality, which is fine. Crafted can get high quality, which has better stats.  Crafting makes more money than it costs, even at low levels. Some items cost 20gil (gold) in ingredients but sell for 500 or more, especially more if it's High Quality.  HOUSING Don't bother. It costs 20 million for a house on my server (the oldest one). 100 hours into the game and I've made 140 000 gil and I'm not even max level yet. I haven't focused on making money but I have been preparing for it. I can make some good coin selling whatever I find but I'm a hoarder and so far my hoarding paid off.  ♥♥♥♥ THEY DONT TELL YOU There's this thing called retainers. These are NPCs you hire. They are needed to sell stuff on the market (trading post). They are also your bank/storage. You get 2 for free.  These retainers can be sent on ventures. That means they will go and gather items for you. Either monster drops, mining, woodcutting or fishing.   You can sell 20 items(for example 20 stacks of items totalling for example 1500 items, so not individual items.) per retainer.   Ventures, unlike what you may read in outdated posts on the internet, are super cheap to buy.  Here's what they don't tell you: You can buy additional retainers, for real money, at about 1-2 bucks per month. This is on top of the subscription fee.  Some don't like that. I don't really care. It may be a reason not to get the game.   It essentially is monthly microtransactions in a sub game.  Speaking of microtransactions... there's a lot of cosmetic things that can go up to and over 25 bucks. Like mounts.   I HAVE NOT REACHED ENDGAME YET I'll update this if I remember to do so.  ---------------------------- OLD VERSION  Friend told me to get this game. Spent the 10 bucks... Been maybe 7 hours since I installed and am still on char creation screen waiting for the server to open.  This may be a common issue in this type of MMO, having full servers and then having to wait and refresh and wait for a spot to open up, waiting for hours or days... it still means you're not actually playing...  While the server selection screen has nice sparklers and new age music harp music, it's not really all that fun.

my recommendation is a 51/49 yes  the game is fun up until you get to end-game (at least from when this review is written, we'll see future updates)  but they are abusing player's time  if you wanna do end-game things, you better not have a IRL job and no friends to play with, because you're never going to get maxed jobs/classes (jobs as in gathering + crafting) with all fully equipped  there's not enough time to do all that, mainly because of how limited you are, /450 gathering/crafting points a week for example...  also for the anima weapon (the very end-game weapon you can get) there are, at the moment, 3 steps to level it... one is doing some fates... that... ok... takes maybe 2-3 hours for each things in that step (like on 5-6 maps)  then it's doing dungeons, also easy  then you need to farm different things, but if you wanna play more casually, like me and my friend, you need to farm EVERY DAY NON STOP FOR 3 MONTHS!! no joking, it's about 87 days... the tribe quests (not the last, vanu one, which would be even worst) but the 4 other tribes  those tribe quests takes like 30 mins to do a day... IF you're lucky and not get into fate quests because some of them can take 30 mins or even 1h to 1h30 to pop (that one in sylph tribe...)  ok i'll be nice and inform about the reason of it being so slow : i sometimes do them at night and there's no one playing, so no one doing the fates and so it takes longer to pop those ones you need  so farm it for 3 months is the best casual-way   and in that same step afterwards you need to craft 4 times each 4 different items (each one of a different crafting job) in high quality...  so you already need to get your crafting and gathering jobs up to that point... and you can only have 3 job crystals at a time, with that 450 point limit a week it will take forever even with the best items equipped -_-    so basically end game = work-at-farm fest   and this is in 'game' category working isn't playing

So I tried this game for a year. It's time for a honest review.  I must say, the game is fun, but after a while it becomes very repetitive. It's your average everyday MMO, and it's very typical for the Asian Culture to adapt to grinding. This game does involve alot of grinding.   The story is okay. Not yay jump out of your chairs. It is way better than ESO, however, despite lack of voice acting. If not so much of a reader, I won't recommend this game.  PVP is ♥♥♥♥ on here. Not to mention, dead. You'll have a better chance forming up a party and run a dungeon or two, but that eventually gets boring. Speaking of forming a party, you also have to know how to tank, dps, or heal, depending on your role, unless you want to get bagged on and bullied. The community here is somewhat friendly, but there's alot of elitists that somehow feel they're entitled to pick on other players, even though they were all noobs one time.  The game lacks mini games or should I say distractions. Yes, there's Levi's, Fates, Golden Saucer, and Chocobo racing, but it lacks executiuon. The very least, Levi's is all about escorting and battling monsters. Almost the same as doing the quests and hunting. Fates is all about battling and battling mini bosses. Battle, battle, battle another words... Then Golden Saucer is the run down version of the actual Saucer that should've existed from FF7. Only appealing thing behind it is Triple Triad, which is meh, and the Chocobo Racing is a JOKE. Hardly delivers a challenge and lot of the times I feel like I'm racing against NPC's more so than players.   This game will drag the user down pretty quick when it comes to progressing. Unless one really loves to grind, and loves to focus on one class and literally put in the 10-12 hours into the game, one is going to either jump through class to class to be flexible and prevent boredom or one will simply quit because as I will state, the game becomes extremely repetitive.   The race choosing is extremely bias. Not to mention, the gender choice. I've found more male players create their fantasy waifu girl than those who're legit females as one example. It's a very sexist game. There's also more lalafells and mon's in the game than there is the other three races. PRetty much what it boils down to is you're either a sexy cat lady or a jailbait child.   Last but not least, the membership. This is a luxury game, you have to remember this. It's graphics and battle mechanics are WAY worth purchasing than WOW's; however, depending on how much of a character lover you are, this game will hurt your wallet per month. It doesn't have benefits behind what one chooses, unless one is willing to pay 14.99 or more depending on the contract one signs. Then one will receive small bonuses throughout the veteran program this game makes, getting costumes, mounts, etc. But nothing good or valid that is worth pursuing.   So here's a brief review of what I experienced in the game. I come back every now and then, sure, but this game doesn't attach to me. I come from Runescape. I don't wish to play traditional turn base MMO's anymore. They get repeitive and boring. This game has also turned into a fashion rolemodel, and not an actual FF game. Which is why I left out of the other con's I've mentioned.  Hope this helps.

Background: Huge Final Fantasy Fan, Bought a PS4 just for FF7 Remake. Anyways!  Replayability: Now this is a weird one. You can swap out the class of your character by merely going into the menus, and putting the correct equipment on. You then get to experience that class story. It is actually 100% recommended and I would go as far as to say it is required as you need at least 2 classes to obtain the Advanced Classes. But this is true for most Final Fantasy Games.  Combat Options: Final Fantasy XIV is the 2nd attempt at a FF Themed MMORPG. For those of you with vast FF backgrounds the Combat type is FFXII with more control of your character placement and equipment slots. For those not familiar with FFXII it is an Active Time battle played out in the general vicinity of enemy spawn points, meaning you can run by just physically running away but you can also attract more enemies as well.   Social Options: The game has been around enough to have many guilds on every instance Server. Experience is shared between those who participate, not just the initial aggressor which means you can't 100% kill steal something, which is a problem in other games.   Final Thoughts: I have since retired from this game after 628 hours due to Burnout...I have great respect for those who continue the good fight, but I just can't continue.

At first, the game seems amazing. Bright, fun world to explore, challenging content, all these classes and jobs to learn... It was really fun getting into. I became obsessed with getting gear, learning rotations, learning the ins and outs of my main classes. It has to be said, tab-targeting hotkey combat may not be for everyone (and if its not go ahead and stop reading and don't play this game), but for me at least there's something extremely satisfying and enjoyable in that itself. Button mashing, trying to max your DPS, or desperately trying to hold aggro with low level Paladin (kms). It left me with a sense of reward and accomplishment when I cleared something for the first time, or got player commendations.   Leveling and experiencing everything for the first time was amazing. And the ability to swap to a different class (on the same character which is an AMAZING mechanic) and learn the class was enough to create the same illusion. But that illusion wore off on me.   Then I saw that I was basically doing the same thing, over and over again, and not really getting any different results. Hmm isn't that called insanity?  The RNG system just isn't too... forgiving. I rarely actually get better gear from dungeons/raids. So what are my other options for endgame gear? Incredibly tedious tasks like farming boring dynamic events, running old dungeons, running the same dungeon over and over again just to get currency to buy the things I need to just get a single STEP closer to that one weapon. Or doing raids in pubs where the party doesn't work together properly and you wipe several times, and again, just for an RNG shot at gear. Granted, if I had an huge, active FC I wouldn't have to deal with pubs but, that wasn't the case for me.   I've taken several breaks, trying to come back over and over to chase that feeling I initially had starting out when everything was still fresh. But for me, it just got the point where I asked myself, why do I keep resubbing? I'm not motivated to do anything because its all more of the same. To be honest, the best part about the game at this point for me is how cute my catgirl character is. Dressing her up with glamour is about all I do, so I think it's time I really stop throwing more and more money into this grindfest and put towards something that doesn't make me feel bored and exhausted. I'm bored and exhausted at my part-time job but they pay me for it, I don't pay them lol.  So overall, if you want to try something new or are coming from a different MMO, at least try it out for a little while, get as much use out of it as you can. But don't let the completionist part of you take over and suck the life out of you like it did me. Because this game is a black hole of grind. If you want to come even close to being geared out, this black hole will absorb all your light. (yay astronomy references) At least in grindy games like Diablo or Warframe, the combat and envirornments and variety of ways to play the game keep you interested. Maybe I just don't like MMORPG's?  If you're looking for a grindfest slot machine / quest completing simulator this is your game. If you're looking for something more entertaining and exciting, the erotic role play in this game can only go so far.  I did enjoy some of my time in this game (mostly the ERP), but I'm going to have to say I don't recommend this game. The overwhelming amount of crap I had to do and time I wasted just doesn't out weight it. And most people give this game positive reviews so I'm like screw em. I sold my Pink DDPAT AWP to buy my last sub, and it's wasted :'(

I do not recommend this game. For the following reasons I cannot recommend anyone spend their time on this game without significant improvements made to account set up and initial updating.  In life there are certain necessities: obtaining resources, developing skills, overcoming obstacles and entertainment to name a few. What motivates one must satisfy a need with a reasonable investment of time and effort. My sole purpose in this game is to play as an imaginary character in an imaginary world filled with imaginary things. As a purchaser I cannot make money, or update my resume with anything related to this effort which is now becoming something of an unjustifiable obstacle relative to the outcome.  I will now chronicle the genesis of this obstacle in order to play as an imaginary character in an imaginary world filled with imaginary things (a meager need that has yet to be satisfied):   1.) I purchased the game on steam and installed it - no problem.   2.) Upon starting the game I needed to set up a Square Enix account which I attempted to do through the launcher (naturally, as the option is provided right there). In my experience, this was a convoluted, glitchy process that resulted in several attempts and approximately two hours of my time wasted. As setting up an account is usually a straightforward process I did not make a log like a dutiful beta tester. Essentially, my email was at once recognized to the extent I could not repeat the registration process to clarify what might have gone wrong, yet not recognized to the extent I could not recover a password. Eventually I simply made an account directly through the Square Enix website. A painless, wonderful and perfectly pedestrian result that by comparison had me shouting joyfully 'It's alive! It's alive' with Handel's 'Messiah' ringing in my head.  3.) After the account was set up I could then update the game. Whereas the registration was likely to have different results for different people depending on wind currents caused by butterfly wings and their relationship to which particle collider test had run on a that day with reference to the alignment of various celestial bodies, the size of the update is massive - and is taking a long time.  With reference to needs and motivation I have run a gauntlet with no satisfaction in sight for another 1386 minutes, and at this point am making two major recommendations:   1.) If the option to create an account via the launcher is intended, it needs to be as simple as creating an account on the website. My experience has shown a discrepancy in ease of use between the two.  2.) The initial update is as massive as the investment of time required for the game to be ready to play; a possible way to mitigate this is to sell a more recent version. If this has no effect on overall download time, find ways to make it more effiecient.  At this point I will complete the updating process, but cannot recommend this game unless these two recommendations are given serious consideration. Butterfly wings and all.   Update: Day1 of gameplay. Still can't recommend this game due to problems out of the gate, but the game itself seems pretty solid.  Aesthetics are very pleasing while keeping the kibble to a minimum; map so far looks good.  No comment on quests yet as I have not progressed much past the tutorial.  Overall get the feeling the learning curve for the game is worth the patience it will take to master.

The final blow for me came when I realized I only had a limited amount of Leve missions and I had wasted them on early levels for my alternative class (to unlock my first job), which meant I would have to wait several days for my Chocobo. The idea that I would have to run around for three days was just mindnumbingly traumatic for me, so I logged off and said goodbye, with only minimal sadness. I would suggest trying out the two week trial before paying for this game. Some people might like it, but most don't seem to.

It's okay, but since ive played World of Warcraft there isn't really any MMORPG that compete. Even know WOW still holds its throne. Sadly for a game that offers better graphics fails at where a game as old as WOW can still be it at, immersive gameplay. In WOW you can walk an entire contentinet without a loading screen anywhere and there isnt a load screen in any parts of the city. In FF14 that isn't the case each area has to load and the cities though not very big still have to load different parts of it. It's almost like a trade off, you get really nice Final Fanasty graphics but loose the immersive gameplay that WOW offers in a seemless open world. FF14 has great graphics close up but background drops and things in the distant it feels like they kinda gave up. Whereas in WOW you can go to anywhere you can see. Though wow does have the greatest graphics i admit, it honestly has an artstyle to it that i think most people perfer to than what FF14 has to offer. The questing system is really boring in the game. Not to say the the questing system in WOW was much better but they were a little bit more tolerable to say the least. In FF14 they have some much heavy dialog as you would expect from a FInal Fanasty game, and makes the questing drag out and i found myself really not caring why i was doing the quest and it didnt have an impact for the game. WOW on the other hand has the new 'phasing' where if you do a certain quest change you can impact the world around you which is a awesome feature to have a MMORPG. FF14 hasnt had anything like that and i feel like i just dont do anything significant in game. Leveling from 1-15 feels ALOT and i mean ALOT slower than leveling in WOW. In FF14 it took 13 hours to reach 15. WOW has made the leveling system more smoother and faster, getting to level 15 in just 4 hours. All in all its not bad, but if you're looking for a MMORPG to play and you haven't looked or played any other MMORPG then this game might be fun for you. But since i have played WOW i have a higher standard that WOW set forth.

If you need a game to spend an (awful) lot of time on, then look no further. Final Fantasy XIV: A realm Reborn is all that you will need, especially with the huge amount of quests and side quests that the game currently has to offer.  Like any MMORPG, FFXIV ARR has different classes, that all work differently. Tanks being the Warrior (Maurauder) and Paladin (Gladiator), the healers being Scholar (Arcanist) and White mage (Conjurer), and finally, the DPS being Dragoon (Lancer), Summoner (Arcanist), Black Mage (Conjurer), Monk (Pugilist), ninja (Rogue) and Bard (Archer). Each class has plenty of abilities to explore, and all play differently, so there's definitely a lot of content there.   That being said, I don't think all classes are equally fun to play. Dragoons and Warriors aren't the funnest to play, but the fun classes definitely make up for that. My personal reccomendations would be:  Tank: Paladin Healer: White Mage & Scholar DPS: Monk, Black Mage, Summoner  Classes themselves are a lot of fun to explore, especially because the way the game handles classchanges: just simply change weapon, and your character becomes that class. No need for additional characters, or a lot of abra cadabra to change around a class, but very straight forward and easy. Even a casual outfit is possible, for in your 'spare time', and hiding your weapons / headpieces on these is done with the single click of a button.   Besides combat classes, the game also offers multiple jobs to do, which you can also access with the same system. It's possible to craft your own weapons and armor with the different classes the game has to offer, or make extra Gil (= in game currency) with gatherers or with the same professions. Although not all of them are equally fun, there's plenty of fun to be had here as well. The only classes i don't really recommend here, except maybe for the gil, are miner, fisher and cook. Sadly, cooking seems a bit pointless in the game from as far as i've found out, except for slight XP boosts, or some additional effects.   The classes are easy to understand and straight forward. If you level one class far enough, you even get the possibilty to use certain abilities of one class on another, in a nice cross class system. Say for example you have a level 50 warrior, and want to use tank abilities that your level 18 gladiator has. It would be possible to have a couple of these abilities on your high leveled warrior, for more tanking badassery.   That's enough ♥♥♥♥ about the classes, now onto the juicy quests and most important of all, the badass l00t! :D  ♥♥♥♥'s good. Go get it.   But in all seriousness, although there are a lot of 'Go fetch', 'travel 'round the world for me' and 'go feed dem soldiers, guardian of light' missions, which unfortunately are boring and a lot of running around, the GOOD missions definitely make up for this. You can go into dungeons, trials (read bosses), guildhests (read tutorials) can farm F.A.T.E's (read events) and leves (read ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of xp for 'allowances'). Most of them definitely help level up your character, but when you reach max level, only trials, dungeons and raids would be in your interest, along with marks. These give you the epic l00t you were looking for :3  You don't have to l00t the defeated enemies, but drops will automatically be added to your inventory.   If you didn't feel like reading it all, there's also a TL,DR version:  TLDR:  ♥♥♥♥'s good. Classes be fun. L00T epic. Go buy it.

If you love mmorpg's this is the game for you. It has a fun, exiting, deep, and unique story that you want to pay attencion to. Nothing in this game is repetitive at all, so if you come from an another mmo you don't feel like you have played it before. The combat system is amazing, and dungeons, raids and trials are so much fun! Each role pays a big part when you play together with someone, so you feel like you are really into it and helping out. The game itself is beautiful, the scenery, world, and even small things like the grass is so pretty, and I think this is unique for an mmo. The character creation is good as well. The game's comunity is also really good, every time I was new to a dungeon people told me things I needed to know. Even when I was just out in the world killing monsters random players helped me, but ofcourse like every other community there are some bad people as well. Overall this is a great game you'll get stuck into, don't mind the subscribtion fee, it is worth playing, and if you can get some friends to play it with you it turns into one of the best games you've ever played, I can guarantee it.

After spending hundreds of hours loged in game (and even more before I started using the steam client version), I have to say this game is my obsession. Everything about it oozes quality from the brilliant music, to the way all the classes work so well together to the storyline that pulls you in. The game as enough pull for casual players and enough grinding and raiding for the hardcore. Best Final Fantasy ever? Probabily not, that still sits as VI for me, but the game's pretty damn close.

The games start is a bit slow, but its beautiful its story in enticing if you are willing to watch the cutscenes, read what they say and all around entice yourself in the world.  The combat is fluid, and easy to use compared to Final Fantasy 11, and the world is very beautifully crafted.  The ability to switch between classes imbetween combats, allows you to find the role you enjoy playing or take part in many roles throughout the day without losing progress in the games story, quests, or ect.  Dungeons in the game, and many foes outside of them require you to move out of spells, or react to required situations in the fight, moving to protected zones during large aoe attacks, or in a particular one, climbing onto a creature for a duration of the fight.  But by far the best part of the game for me, is that it is truely beautiful. Take time to observe each creature in the game, and the zones they live in and you will see how much work was put into them.

*I actually already put in about 40 more hours but not through the steam launcher.  FFXIV doesn't try to change the MMORPG genre, but it refines and streamlines a lot of it. It's quicker, looting is instant, inventory management is easier, crafting is more fun, and you can train all classes and jobs on one toon - and leveling new ones is much easier once you unlock the repeatable quests.   It also plays great with a controller (esp for tank, it seems harder for magic) though I keep a keyboard / mouse handy for non combat stuff.   The negatives are that it still includes fetch quests, it's not really made for duoing (I really like to play games with my romantic partner, but they didn't get into it as much as it feels a bit less strategic at the start.) I also wish you got to choose some skill progression within your class, but you do get to customize a fair bit by choosing cross class skills once you unlock them by leveling a new class.   There's a lot more to say but I don't need to say it all, check out some other reviews.

TL;DR: The most boring and unengaging MMORPG I have ever played. Read further for my rant, the one thing I like, and the few things I really don't like.  *NOTE: Edit at the bottom of the initial review bcause apparently I didn't play enough of it to be engaging.*  Okay, first of all I really wanted to like this game and I understand it's hard to recommend an MMO as everyone will have different experiences, but I'd heard such nice things about it, and was really looking forwards to playing it. I find that FFXIV is the most unengaging MMORPG I have ever had the pleasure of playing, the combat is unintuative, I sit there pressing 1 and then comboing it with 3 before the combo resets. A small nitpick is the fact that for a AAA made game, and a sub based MMO at that, the majority of cutscenes, (cough the first intro one that takes a good few minutes to get through and is unskippable cough) are completely devoid of any voice acting.  I would highly recommend playing a game such as Guild Wars 2 over this, or if you want to stay on Steam, a F2P MMORPG my friend and I dabbled with for a while was Aura Kingdom, which we both agree is more engaging than this.  Edit Start: Okay so apparently I didn't play enough of it for the game to get engaging? But let me get this straight, if a game isn't engaging afer playing it for 6 hours, how is that any fun for me? So I thought, hell, I'll try get it to 10 hours to please Ms Valenska here, but I just couldn't do it. 1 hour short but whatever.  I'd like to rephrase my first point here. It shouldn't take more than 6, sei, 六, шесть, seis, six, HOURS for a game to get engaging. If it takes longer than that, then what the hell is the point in playing it. Sure for RPGs, or more specifically MMORPGs, there's always the 'endgame' to look forwards to, but in all honesty, this game just doesn't get there. I'm not going to waste any more time of my life trying to play this game, running half way across a continent to deliver some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s letter to try accumulate enough experience just to see if there's a nice light at the end of the tunnel. I'd rather continue my Greater Rift runs on Diablo 3 or actually get back into Raiding in World Of Warcraft, hell playing FFXIV got me wanting to get back into playing Guild Wars 2 so there's one thing I can thank it for.  Also a side point, good on you, Arena Net. You made a great MMORPG, and guess what? It has voice acting for basically ALL of the quests. Tell me the first thing you notice when you boot up FFXIV A Realm Reborn and start a new character. That cart scene, no voice acting? I know right, such a long intro cinematic and NO VOICE ACTING for a good at least 5 minutes. Thanks, Squeenix, for making an AAA MMORPG and actually caring about your cinematics as much as you do in your other Final Fantasy games. So thanks, Arena Net, for giving your NPCs actual character and personality, even if it ISN'T a main quest line.  I feel the only thing that I like about FFXIV is being able to join multiple guilds and have multiple possible 'professions', sick of being a Gladiator? Well go down and change into a Rogue, or even a magic weilding class. Honestly, that is the only part I liked.  Like I stated before, the combat is a monotonous combo of pressing one key, and then comboing it with another that gives it a little bonus. Then rinse and repeat. I really wanted to get my Rogue to level 30 to train into a Ninja as you have to do actual hand signs to perform Ninjutsu, which honestly that is an awesome idea, unfortunately I don't have the patience to level up my Rogue another 15 levels in the same monotonous grind involving ferrying letters from one continent to another, kill about 5 enemies for a small quest, and then take another letter back to the other side of the continent because clearly the mail service in this fantasy realm isn't good enough.  If I regret buying something, in all honesty it would be this game, which I will definitely not be resubbing to any time soon. If you're a die hard Final Fantasy fan, and you loved the idea of playing an FF MMO (well there's always FFXI which could even be better but I'm not gonna risk it), you will most likely actually like this game, the same way I love Fallout 3 with all it's bugs and flaws.  But for anyone who isn't super big on Final Fantasy, be wary, it will be very hit and miss. I'd recommend trying some Free 2 Play MMOs first, Aura Kingdom, Neverwinter, Star Wars The Old Republic, RIFT, even The Elder Scrolls Online now that it's going F2P. You can go the Buy 2 Play route and opt to get Guild Wars 2, which will offer you a whole game for one payment. Though the best Pay 2 Play MMORPG, in my experience and that i have played, is World Of Warcraft, and there is no way that Final Fantasy XIV A Realm Reborn could live up to the standard WoW has set, and that is in my opinion of course.  As the very first sentence states (the TL;DR sentence), I just find this game very, very unengaging and boring, so buyers be wary if you're unsure. There are plenty of better choices for MMORPGs out there.

An mmo with class! I blame my friend Magmawk for this.  Graphics: I have to say, everything is frakking beautiful. This is literally the most beautiful mmo I have ever played. It's not catroony coloful like TERA is, this game just look beautiful. Not just is there a lot of detail on npcs and enemies, but even enviremnets look great! The spells and special attacks all come with bright and colorful effects and really put pizzaz on your stuff! In fact, the quest where you have to look for vistas is like the game saying 'LOOK HOW BEAUTIFUL I AM!'  Sound: The sound of this game is awesome. The music sounds great and always feels perfect for the setting they play in. None of the music is boring and I love listenig to it! The attacks sound like they have impact and the monsters and npcs really sound good! The voice acting is also very well done and amazing. Turn the volume up on this one!  Control: While I use a controller for this game (to great effect), keyboard/mouse also works quite well. And the game lets you organize your skillbars to make even easier for you.  Gameplay: While on your initial class, there is no shortage of quests to complete, FATEs to run, and Leves to do, as wel as hunting logs to complete. WIth all that, it takes no time to level up. Once you hit the level cap for a class, you stop gaining exp, so finishing no-50 quests becomes a waste of exp. But you can switch to other classes at time, so exp is not wated. And there are a LOT of classes to choose from! But once you have completed most of the non-50 quests, the only good sources of exp come from FATEs and Leves. And if you want access to the JOBs, you have to level up another class to unlock it. Thankfully, there are many Level 50 quests that will keep you entertained. From the Hildebrand quests to Crystal Tower and the Coils of Bahamut, you will have things to do for a long time. And with classes like Culinarian and Armorer, you can get your crafting on and really make some money on the market, which is admitadly slightly broken right now abusable it is in making Gil. My only issues are ;that the classes/jobs neatly fit into 3 basic catgories of TANK/HEALER/DPS with little way of customizing (only 2 tank classes, 2/3 healer clasess and 11 dps); and that it can be annoying waiting in a queue for a dungeon to launch (tanks and healers are usuallly rare). Better have a group if you want to run dungeons for quicker queues.  There is some grinding on other classes, but it's not as much as other mmos and the story and dungeons are fun enough to keep playing over and over! If you are looking for a truly great mmo, I highly reccomend this one! It may not be free, but it is worth EVERY PENNY!

This is a very typical, yet extremely polished and well-made MMORPG. If you like traditional MMOs, this is going to keep you busy for months. It has an emphasis on endgame content, storytelling and incredible boss design. The best thing about the game, though, is likely the fact that there is NO microtransaction market. If you have a subscription, EVERYTHING in the game is available to you, and EVERY item in the game is earned, and not bought. If you see someone riding around on a sweet mount, they worked for that. They didn't just pull out their credit card. I know this shouldn't be a major selling point, but unfortunately it's just about the only MMO to come out in the last decade to do this. I recommend it completely for any MMORPG fan, but if you don't like MMOs, and just love Final Fantasy, it may not be for you. At the low price it costs, though, it's worth a try regardless.

Final Fantasy XIV is such a well-shapen game. It has beautiful environments, amazing battle mechanics, and a captivating backstory. My only complaints are that if one decides to purchase the game through Steam, they may have to wait a few hours before their purchase actually goes through. Also, the game has MANY connection issues. I remember I was in the middle of a dungeon run and I got disconnected from the game without any warning. Usually, a red circle with some diagonal lines inside will appear next to your name indicating that you are having connection issues. But that time, I did not get such a warning. And it's a shame really, for as beautiful as this game is, it has quite a few problems, which apparently occured before past updates as well. I think the game will need time to develop more if these problems are to be resolved. But if you encounter no such errors, then I suppose there is no problems there.
