So FFXIV...  I have sunk countless hours in to this game on my ps3 and then on to my PS4. I have achieved max level on almost everything this game offers.  This game is very beautiful, probably one of the most beautiful MMOs I have ever played. Unfortunatly, I find that this game (like most MMOs these days) doesn't offer enough to keep players like myself around. At first glance the instances are super fun, the boss fights with enemies like Ifirit and Garuda are amazing and require a lot of team work. But then you have to run those same bosses over and over and over again. Good job, now go do it again on 'hard mode', and then the next mode, and then coils over and over countless times, I understand 'the grind' is a part of a lot of MMOs and RPGs, and to some respect I love it myself, but I feel there needs to be more substance to the game to warrant a grind like this.  This is a great game and the devs continue to add more to it. It's hard for me to put a finger on it exactly, it just seems to fall a little short. For a more 'casual' gamer in this genre, you will fit right in and fall in love. For someone like myself, the game will become boring and you will move on (most times), BUT, I do recommend giving it a shot. It's a great game and maybe with the upcoming expansion and the content patches that continue to come dowm this game may get even myself to come back.  All in all, this is a great game that tends not to hold the interest of players (certainly not everyone will fall in to this) long enough. Worth the experience at 'the right price'.  7/10

I did this out of boredom, and I don't want to proof read. Sorry readers.  Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn (2.0) is a reboot of the failure that was Final Fantasy XIV 1.0.   FF14: ARR is said to be a fairly casual MMO, and I can't deny it. I don't have a lot of MMO experience, but I can tell the game is slow-paced. That being said, this game is very easy to pick up and there is no built-in DPS meter, so no one can say you're bad without letting everyone know they're using a third party program (Illegal, oh no! But Square Enix doesn't care if you use a third party program, as long as you don't call other people out on doing subpar damage. How nice.) The game does cater to the casual crowd more often than not, and as a result some people seem to be absolutely clueless when it comes to playing their class. I sometimes wish Square could throw in a DPS meter so DPS would be encouraged to not be dumpster-tier when they see that a healer or tank is doing more DEEPS than they are.  The races in this game are very similar: human (Hyur), human with cat ears and a tail (Miqo'te), giraffe humans (Elezen), big human (Roegadyn), and potato/little human (Lalafell) and with the upcoming expansion, demon/dragon human (Au'ra). There are differences between the races of course, but there is nothing too drastic between them. Square played it safe and decided not to include actual beast races, as cool as that would be. Maybe in the second expansion Square will realize they're making bank and that people actually want a beast race (see Au'ra concept art that got dropped. Jesus, why'd you do it Yoshi-P?). Expect a lot of c@girls running around, often half naked, coolcool. Character creation isn't the game's strong point, there are no sliders unfortunately, so you can't make a monster like you could in Oblivion or Skyrim or anything of the like (as fun as that would be). A lot of characters do look similar and that leads to people trying to make special snowflake characters that look atrocious.   The game is by no means perfect; there are good aspects of it in the middle of all the bad. It's a fun game with a lot of content to do. The story is pretty good in my opinion, nowhere near the caliber of FF6. That being said, there are a lot of references to previous FF games. Off the top of my head, there's a Crystal/Sycrus Tower raid (FF3), an Ultros & Typhon Fight (FF6), a FF13 event which had Lightning appear in Eorzea. And I'm sure there's a multitude of other references I've missed or forgotten.   The sound was one of the first things I took note of when I started playing the game. I was captured by the ambient noise, the music (the music in the game is especially great), the sound effects, everything; everything sound-related is great. What I love the most is the weather sound effects, my personal favourite being the stormy weather, it really does sound great with the lightning and rain sfx. The game is very pretty and quite colourful (minus some select areas), if you're starting out I suggest choosing a class that starts in Gridania. Gridania is super comfy with its music and environment and has the most simplistic layout of the 3 starting areas. The graphics aren't as good as FF14 1.0, but that game required a supercomputer to run smoothly. My game runs fine on medium settings with a computer built in 2009.  The community in this game is very friendly except for a small minority. Most will go out of their way to help other people and it really does encourage people (someone like me who's turned into an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ because of LoL & DotA 2) to be as helpful as I can be. I'm guessing that the community is so nice is because a good portion of it is from FF11, so don't be surprised to see married people, or even parents playing the game.   As I've said before, the FF14 we have now is a reboot of its 1.0 iteration, after the failure of 1.0, Square had to play it safe, which pretty much explains the casualness of the game, alongside the seemingly similar races.  It's definitely not the best game out there. Updates are plentiful & full of content; the game is easy to get into, a lot of throwbacks to previous FF games, half naked c@girl waifus if you're into that, good sound and a friendly community.   This review is garbage and I don't know why anyone would have bothered to read it or why I even typed it out. Thanks for reading anyways, though.  My opinions are definitely influenced by the poeple of /xivg/, thanks a lot for making me see the bad in one of my favourite games.

No character customization.  Well, appearance... yes... what class you are... sure.  Stats and what skills you get? Well, that's all automatic.  That's right. FFXIV took a progression option that was available since the days of Ragnarok Online and tore it from our hands. Even in the single player FF games, such as FFVI, FFT, FFX, etc, etc, you got to select skills and build your characters as needed. No, you didn't choose your stats individually, but they each had a bevvy of skills you could browse around and choose when you leveled up.  Not in this.  What skills you get at what level are pre-determined from the moment you select your class.  Yes, the story is... neat. The graphics are... on par with what you'd expect FF to have. The voice-overs are absolutely abhorrant though.  Yeah, you can change classes as easily as changing equipment. (Remember FFX-2?)  You even have individual levels for each class, and get to use skills from your other classes. One of these is a shot in the foot and the other is a gift-wrapped shoe box.  However, take into account that every level 50 character is basically the same. There's 5 different races, (all of them are variations of human... really...) The only thing that'll differ is equipment, which I'm sure is a situation you'll have to grind for.  As someone who enjoys the journey more than the destination, (I hate end-game emphasis...) I cannot recommend a game that cookie-cutters each character into the same underlying thing.  Also, I bet I could recommend the game if it gave your character more options than to follow this 'new adventurer & one of the chosen' path.  Geez, Squeenix, you're so worried about making sure everything is always balanced for everyone in your MMORPG, you left me sad for my nostalgia and what the series has become.

Full Disclosure: This is my first edit of this review.  In my original review I did not recommend this game because of constant harassment from RMT third parties that was part of the game at this time. Thanks to decisions and changes made by SquareEnix this problem has been largely resolved and harassment is almost non-existent (and can be made so with proper chat filtering)  With the most serious problem of the game in the past I change my review to a recommended.  • • • • • • • • • •  Final Fantasy XIV is a hotkey MMO that takes what is popular with the genre and gives at the Final Fantasy series treatment. From the visuals to the music to the sound effects to the narrative approach the modern SquareEnix/Final Fantasy theme is everywhere (and that's a good thing, especially for fans of the entire series).  Gameplay-wise FFXIV is a solid experience that enthusiasts of the genre will enjoy. 4-man instances, 8-man or 16-man raids, with auto-group finding tools, ensure content comes quick and nigh on-demand. If there is a gripe about the gameplay I have it is the long-winded global cooldown on many abilities each of the classes have... genre enthusiasts have been playing with global cooldowns for a decade now and are used to them, but more action oriented players will have a touch of adjusting to deal with. It is a minor gripe to an otherwise great experience.  If you want a solid hotkey MMO entry to lose yourself in, Final Fantasy XIV is a good canidate. It's true to the game type and has enough content to keep you involved a long while. For me, not a huge fan of the hotkey MMO, I'm enjoying the game if only for the Final Fantasy atmosphere. Recommended.
Only MMO I am willing to pay a subscription for month after month.

** Update **  I let my subscription run out due to the gold spamming. I was blocking 20-25 spammers on weekdays and 25+ on weekend days. When I have to write a macro to blacklist and report spammers I know the situation isn't being handled, despite my reporting Every last one of them for a month straight. Pity, too. The storyline is good and I was beginning to enjoy dungeons.  ** End Update**  It's alright, though I'd recommend going with the free trial they have on their site before purchasing. There are limits on the trial version but it should be enough of a taste to determine whether you'd like this game or not. Crafting is nice but I made the error of taking up too many skills which has led to a serious space issue. You won't be able to use the market (sell to other players) until completing the level 17 storyline quest, that's also when you get additional storage in the form of retainers (125 slots each, 2 free retainers).  They've got great ideas going on, but again, space is turning out to be a major issue. You'll be given 100 spaces for everything except armor and crafting clothing - those go into a separate storage area. The problem is 100 spaces goes quickly when you're able to collect high quality crafting items in addition to regular quality.  Say you're working on cotton. You'll collect cotton bolls and you'll likely end up with high quality (HQ) and regular. That's 2 spaces. Then you have to craft that into Yarn. Again, HQ and regular. That's 4 spaces. That yarn gets made into cloth. HQ and regular. 6 spaces. You use Both yarn and cloth in recipes so you don't get to reclaim space by using up the yarn. A few recipes require the raw material, yarn and cloth so don't bet on using up all the raw materials to reclaim space.  Hemp comes before cotton. So you'll have 6 spaces taken up by hemp because you can't trade on the market, yet, nor will you have your retainers. You won't want to vendor the hemp HQ items because they sell decently to players, so that's at least 3 spaces you're using to hold on to that hemp. 9 spaces for Weaving. Ahhh, but that's not all! You don't get away that easily. Some recipes require additional items like leather or beast sinew.  So, until at least level 17 you're going to be juggling space. At level 25 you can get your two free retainers. A retainer stores 125 items and acts as your liaison for trading on the market board as well as being a gopher. There is housing available at level 50, but that's still a ways off and if you wait until level 17 or 25 to start crafting you're going to be playing a game of catch up.  Gameplay isn't bad in a group. Solo is slow at the lower levels I was still not able to one-shot a level 2 mob at level 20. That's because gear is limited at the lower levels and there aren't many stats to be had to boost your character. It doesn't detract from gameplay or make questing difficult, but when you need all that leather that falls from lvl 1 & 2 mobs it's going to take a while to collect what you need due to cool downs on skills and the lack of being able to one-shot minor mobs. FATEs are a good way to gain that leather fast because you're usually hitting the same mob as other folks, making the kills go faster.  All-in-all we're enjoying the game, but tweaks would certainly be appreciated.  Oh, and the gold spam is out of control. However, you can set your status to Busy. This blocks (everyone) from sending you tells so no gold spam. It also blocks Free Company (guild) invites, which players like to spam you with.

At this point, writing a review is a bit like asking Gordon Ramsay if he likes to cook. I have nearly 300 hours in this game as of writing, and I've enjoyed every single one of them. Also I manage perfectly well to balance my study with this game. If anything it actually IMPROVED my performance, it drives me to work harder during the day so I have more free time during the evenings to play.  The good: + Summarized: This game takes everything from other MMOs that works, strips out what doesn't work, and innovates on features in its own way. + The dev team is very much aware that the original FFXIV had a horrible start, and their mantra is 'earn and deserve the players' trust'. They deliberately chose to keep the game subscription-based because it offers them and the players more stability. + The cross-server Duty Finder lets you queue up for every form of cooperative content from wherever you are in the world. + Big bonuses for people who repeat old content in the Duty Finder (sadly only once per day), to encourage keeping storyline content populated so you won't get stuck just because you can't find anyone to play with. + Classes are varied and the handful I've tried are fun to play. At level 30, every class evolves into one or two Jobs that are even more specialized. + You can train every class on a single character. In fact most Jobs have a secondary class requirement that also needs to be trained. + There are two levels of subscription, Entry and Standard. Entry is cheaper than Standard, but doesn't allow recurring payments and restricts you to 1 character per server, 8 in total. But since you can just train every class on a single character anyway, this won't actually lock you out of anything. + The world is beautiful and feels alive. + The lore and story are of true Final Fantasy levels, and better than I've seen in any other MMO. + The game tries to do that 'chosen one in a world of chosen ones' that story-heavy MMOs are all guilty of, but actually executes it very well. In-storyline, your character becomes something of a living legend after a while, and everyone acknowledges that you faced off with terrible monsters and lived to tell the tale. When someone does question your skills in the storyline, it's usually because they actually are a fool. + Boss battles are extremely memorable, and all have interesting mechanics. + The music. Oh God, the music. The regular zone music is already plenty good and immersive, but the composer went completely wild with the dungeon and boss themes. Expect epic choires, punk rock and heavy metal. One boss in particular has 5 different phases, and every phase has its own song.'  The middle: ~ Truly understanding the mechanics of your class/job and the role you fulfill in party dynamic takes quite some time and willingness to learn. If someone gives you good advice, listen to it. I learned the most by making mistakes, and getting tips on what I should have done differently from people who were there with me. This process still continues today, and I only get better by it.  The bad: - Levelling alternate classes gets quite grindy. You get massive XP boosts when you level classes that are below the level of your highest class, but even with that you'll need to invest a lot of time past level 30. Your primary class should be fine doing only Main Story Quests most of the time, at least until you reach Heavensward. - You start with a lot of inventory space and even an armoury chest to store your equipment in, but you will inevitably run into the limits of this with how many crafting materials there are in the game, and how many different sets of equipment you need if you play multiple classes. Rather than a bank the game features retainer NPCs which can do something to alleviate the burden, but I think the game would really benefit of a Guild Wars (2) type of crafting material specific storage. - There is a shortage of Tanks and Healers in the Duty Finder queues. But this isn't really the game's fault, and multi-classing makes it easy to just ask a friend to jump in for a role if you really can't find anyone. - Not all parts of the story are equally good, and some characters are very annoying.

This game is all-around a fantastic MMO. One thing I truly enjoy is the community. I remember first starting out and pretty mch everybody helped me out whether it be dungeons, raids, or trials. Even in the end-game content people are helpful an respectful. Granted there thos ewho are impatient, but we all have those days. There is a wealth of content to take part. Many side quests with a few side stories to them. The patches typically bring plenty of new content with them. There are many classes to choose from. Three tanks, 3 healers, and 7 DPS (Damage per second in case you didn't know). The Heavensward DLC brought on a humongous amount of content, and the story wasn't all that bad either. I find the game to most of the time have a positive atmosphere to it and it's very welcoming to new players. I encourage anyone who's thinking about this to try the free trial located on the FFXIV website. One thing I feel the need to say is that among all the servers, last I checked the most populated servers are Balmung and Gilgamesh (I'm on Gilgamesh, transferred awhile back) and you can't typically make new characters on these servers, thus being forced to make a character on another server and paying of $18 to dollars to transfer over to another. That ws the only way I saw to get into the populated servers because at the time I mained a DPS, and the queue times were insane at times. Anywho, I highly reccomend this game.

I played Final Fantasy 11 online for years. Many years like almost ten. I have to say this Game is a newer well implemented version of it that somehow lacks the experiance of the original ff mmo. I really wished the devolopers had added a few more varied classes, a lot more voiced content, and good lord is group voice chat really to much to ask for with a paid sub game? Honestly though i have my gripes it is a wonderful mmo. The crafting is actually pretty fun and it don't take months to reach simple goals like ff11 did. The combat is by far the largest improvement, with abilities that make sense and timers that make sense(ff11 had abilities with two hour cooldowns). the graphics are pretty and are extremely consistant. Its almost like finding an extinct animal alive to find a glitch in this game. The content is varied and entertaining, but there is still quite a few go here kill 10 of these type quests, honestly it's like milking a cow for a half hour sometimes. Meeting people can be tough especially if your kinda gung ho to do what you want, but for the most part the community is very friendly. Rarely you will run into a serious ♥♥♥♥♥♥ on any mmo and no game is the exception. I play with my wife and we like to run the quests or dungeons together, while playing these events if you do not enter with enough players to fill the requirements other players that queud for the same dungeon will be presented the option to join. The dungeons are well crafted fun and can be challenging, but the community at large is very very very unforgiving for mistakes, even from first time runners. The community almost demands you watch video and read guides on the dungeons before you run them, wich can ruin the fun of figuring out the dungeon and diminish the experiance of victory. I have a blast playing even though i've made next to no 'friends' in my time on (seriously i have like two besides my wife) but there are always groups looking to recruit. These groups run the gamut from being awesome community groups to being groups that try to manipulate you and get you to willingly contribute your hard earned resources to the group, then kicking you out of the group for not being elite enough or 'invested' enough. Overall ARR is a well crafted mmo adventure with a fair amount of content and a lot of fun to be had. 8/10

So first time writing a review bout games on steam, but since I liked this one i suppose it's about time.  I'll start with the cons to FFXIV, but please read on cause i do recommend this game to others. - The fact that the game is a p2p game. Even though the Sub has 2 options, for those who can afford to buy the game but can't continue the Sub each month it's a big downer - A strange latency issue which i was told it's cause of where their servers are. - No F2P model at all. If i could make one suggestion to the devs for this game it would be to design an F2P model with a Sub option since that's the way a lot of modern day games are going.  Now for the pros and i won't list them all or this would be a 4 page essay. - Gameplay is easy, but exciting at the same time with having to watch and learn the mechanics of monsters and bosses to dodge frontal and AoE attacks. - The ability to have 1 character be all classes and gear each one the way you want to gear it. - The crafting system and gathering system is very interactive. - Dungoens/Raids have never been this interesting and mind blowing before. It's not just watch for the red carpet mechanics. You got to watch what the bosses do, what they spawn and even how things are placed and killed. - Funny, emotional and down right heart touching quests. The main story will grab you and never let you go, but even the side quests have that effect. - The guild system and community group system is ground breaking. I love the fact that there is your guild system with quite a few costumize options and a housing system for the guild including player housing (recently added), but ontop of that you have linkshells where whole bunch of people from different guilds or even guildless can form a group to chat with and share things with each other. - Everything you loved bout FFXI is still in FFXIV (classes are being added slowly as well) Even though a few of the classes are different from FFXI, there is a lot of the game style and even some class mechanics that was brought over from FFXI.  So even though it has a sub, if you can afford it then i would suggest playing this game over a lot of p2p games out there.

I'm dissapointed. Really was liking this game and then it kinda is getting grindy and not so fun. I'll update again in another week or 2.

This game is 'WoW + Final Fantasy'. Using most WoW's MMO mechanics with little improvements (like Dynamic Events a lot like Guild Wars 2) and the graphical quality and style of old Final Fantasy.  So, if you dislike WoW you'll probably dislike FF:ARR as many game mechanics are taken directly from WoW (looking for groups, characters roles, questing and raids are pretty similar).  The story is quite good for an MMO, just don't expect something life changing. The games art have excellent graphics and animations all around, too.  Endgame bosses can range from quite easy to ultra hard especially if you go for random groups.

I am writing this for the steam version of FFXIV however I only recently started playing it on PC. I have 110 days gameplay logged on the PS4 version, so I feel pretty confident when I say this is hands down my favorite game and one of the most beautiful games ever made. Even after two years of playing this game heavily it continues to be the game I choose above all else. Be warned though, this is not a game that is easily picked up or put down, it has a fairly large learning curve and requires some level of dedication in order to really experience this game the way its meant to be played. you can expect to play 40+ hours a week for about a month before you get to some of the 'endgame' content. Not to discourage anyone thinking of picking it up though, I think everyone should spend some amout of time in FFXIV so as to see what a wonderful world SE has created. It's a must play, 10/10 in my book.

If you love Final Fantasy games and are unsure about picking it up because its a MMO and it'll take away from the experience. Then allow me to reassure you, Even though its an MMO, FFXIV has done it amazingly well with their Story. Taking part with the MMO basics of Dungeons, Raids and Guilds, as well as putting their own twist on it with Aeons/Primals, If you don't get hooked on the fights, The music will get you to come back to them, Each having an amazing soundtrack as it fires you up to fight onward, Coming from someone who enjoys Final Fantasy games in a whole and has put hours upon hours into them, Going to A Realm Reborn was a great refreshing feeling.  So far my best experience is the Trial fights with all the different Primals they have in store for you, Not only in A Realm Reborn, but in the Heavensward Expansion as well. Each having a great impact and leaving you wanting to go at them again and again.  One other thing to mention is that Final Fantasy 14 allows you to change classes at will, so theres no need to make another character to play a different class, You may begin a new class at anytime by talking to their respected Guilds and taking on their Quests.  Long story short, The games great, Ive had countless hours of fun, Trials kept me wanting to come back and VS tough opponents, Dungeons had great mechanics and a great level curve, The music is amazing to listen to, Although it is Pay to Play, You can start a free trial to see if you would like it or not, But Would recommend.

Frankly Final Fantasy XIV is an amazing MMO, and also an amazing game. And it is quite an experience, its MMO aspects are well refined (of course not flawless) and certainly top notch. The story is absolutely great, and in general I think that it is a wonderful experience from the moment you create your character and as you advance through the Main Story Quest (MSQ). While certain elements of the gameplay may feel foreign to some (like the 'long' global cooldown) especially at low level, the game picks up nicely.  And not just that, bu you can see in many things how the developer team cares for the game, from small things like the seasonal events, to the story, music among many other things which is refreshing on a day and age where developers seems to be much more interested in a quick profit, while providing lackluster content. If you love MMORPGs, Final Fantasy XIV is a great game and worth trying it out.  If you are not a fan of Final Fantasy games it doesn't matter, I never played many titles of the franchise before, and was skeptical, as I was quite content with playing World of Warcraft, but this game became a new home to me and I absolutely love it and proof of it is the amount of hours invested in the game.  So TL;DR version  Gameplay: 8/10 Story: 10/10 (it is great and each patch adds more and more story) Music: 9/10 Graphics: 9/10 (its certainly one of the best looking MMOs our there)

Do you love subscription? Do you love Final Fantasy? Do you love Square Enix?  I'm assuming you said 'yes' to the first two and 'no' to the last, right? Normally most people are turned off by the subscription model, but I guarantee you if you are into SE and FF - subscriptions will mean almost nothing to you. This game is worth almost every penny that you put into it and it's highly enjoyable. I'll just go into it below.  Pros: - Class system. With one character, you can play EVERY class in the game. This means you can choose the cheaper sub that restricts you to one character per server versus eight per server. - The community in general is great. There have been a few salty people, but what game doesn't have that? It's very minimal though so don't mind it... unlike League. - Gameplay mechanics is brilliant. It all feels very smooth and actually very fun to plan your next moves (if you like the strategy). - Level syncing. Are you a new player and want to play with friends? Well, you can't join them for obvious reasons, but they can join you with a level sync! Their gear gets toned down to be appropriate to the dungeon/FATE level so it won't be overkill.  - End-game life is actually very enjoyable. You have many options available to you: grind for BIS gear, work on other classes, craft stuff, gather stuff or maybe even help people. - The game provides many different ways of helping you. Dungeons get progressively harder so you can ease into the game or use the party/raid finders to assist you. - The game patches assist those who are new to the game to speed them towards the end-game. For example, I had to restart my progress and I managed to catch up to the 24/7 players within two weeks (might be an overstatement). - The storyline is relatively enjoyable. Sometimes a bit cliche, but the DLC provides a very enjoyable storyline. - THE MUSIC. OH MY GOD, THE MUSIC. SQUARE ENIX GETS IT RIGHT AGAIN. - I personally think the subscription is at a very decent price. I pay £7.69 per month for the entry sub. If you know you'll play for a long time, buy in bulk - it gets even cheaper. - The marriage system, fairly self-explanatory.  - I'll add more pros if I can think of any.  Cons: - The early game. It's very tedious - you usually spam two skills until 26-ish with the occasional other skill. Just hold on, man - you can survive. - The DPS queues early on. When you play as a DPS, you would normally expect that queues are long since it's the most popular role. It does get better later on though, since DPS are needed a lot more. - I'll add more cons if I can think of any.  If you have the money to keep a sub, play it. If you love Final Fantasy, play it. If you love Square Enix, play it.

Fantastic game. Ive been playing this game for over a year now in combination between pc an ps4 and ive loved this game from first time i played the ps4 beta until now and i will continue to love this game. The community is generally very informative and what not and most are willing to help new players through dungeons or whatever you may have questions about. Most of my time in game has been on the leviathan server. The story is a rollercoaster of emotions and badassery im not a fan of Pvp in the game but i never have been for any mmo but all in all this game is absolutely fantastic and really gives something else to the mmo world rather than your typical stuff. Grinding is not a huge part of the game but it is required to play the game in the best way possible. Meaning that you have the ability to use abilities from different classes and you will need to level up other classes to access them. One important thing to note is that you do not have to run alternate characters to experience all of the classes. One character can have all classes and what not for those who really want to get the most out of the game and those who love to hunt for achievements. The sub price is about 15 a month so its on par with mmos such as WoW and what not. You can also pay for your sub through your steam wallet which i find pretty cool. All in all its a great game and worth all the time put in it.
